name: MistralAIModel

input.content:
In freecad I want to have a circle but only for reference not to actually be a circle but just so I can line up other lines to make a hexagon for example.
How do I do that?

output:
In FreeCAD, you can use a construction geometry feature to create reference shapes that won't be part of the final model. This is perfect for your use case of creating a circle for reference to help in constructing a hexagon.

Here's how to create a reference circle using the construction geometry:

1. Open FreeCAD and create a new document if needed.
2. Switch to the "Draft Workbench" if you're not already in it. You can find it in the toolbar at the top or by using the dropdown menu on the left side of the interface.
3. Click on the "Construction" toolbar button or select "Draft → Toggle Construction Mode" from the menu to enable construction geometry mode. The button looks like a blue triangle with white dashed lines. When enabled, the button will appear pressed down.
4. Now you can create a reference circle. Use the "Draft → Circle" command or click the "Circle" button in the toolbar.
5. Specify the center and radius of the circle or use other available methods to define it, like selecting two opposite points to define the diameter.
6. After creating the circle, you can use it as a reference to draw lines tangent to the circle or use other drafting tools to create your hexagon.
7. Once you have finished using the reference circle, you can toggle the construction geometry mode off by clicking on the "Construction" button again. The reference circle will appear faded, indicating that it will not be part of the final model.

Remember to switch back to the regular geometry mode (non-construction mode) before creating shapes that should be part of your final model.

By following these steps, you can create a reference circle in FreeCAD and use it to align other lines to make a hexagon or any other shape you desire.
